resources.string: Take a measurement and you will see overview here

The three-site skinfold test is a method to estimate body fat percentage using skinfold measurements at three specific locations. For men, the common sites are the chest, abdomen, and thigh. For women, the common sites are the triceps, suprailiac, and thigh. The measurements are taken using skinfold calipers and then plugged into gender-specific equations to calculate body density, which is then converted to body fat percentage.

The seven-site skinfold measurement method for assessing body fat involves using calipers to measure subcutaneous fat thickness at specific locations on the body. These locations are the triceps, biceps, subscapular, supraspinale (or suprailiac), abdominal, thigh, and chest. These measurements, when combined, can provide an estimation of overall body fat percentage. It offers slightly better accuracy than three sites skinfold measurement.
Your measurement will not be saved.

I am sharing my body fat percentage with you!

MyBodyFatTracker allows you to calculate bodyfat your body fat percentage using skinfold measurements at three specific locations. For men, the common sites are the chest, abdomen, and thigh. For women, the common sites are the triceps, suprailiac, and thigh. The measurements are taken using skinfold calipers and then plugged into gender-specific equations to calculate body density, which is then converted to body fat percentage.
Welcome to BodyFatTracker. We are committed to protecting your privacy. This Privacy Policy explains how we collect, use, and safeguard your information when you use our mobile application.

We may collect the following information, which is stored locally on your device:
- Personal Identification Information: Name, age, gender.
- Body Measurement Data: Skinfold measurements, body fat percentage results, and related calculations.
- Profile Photo: If you choose to provide one.

We use the information we collect solely to:
- Provide and personalize the app's features (e.g., calculate body fat, display history).
- Allow you to track your progress over time.
All processing and calculations are performed locally on your device.

All your personal information and measurement data are stored locally on your device within the application\'s private storage. We take reasonable measures to protect your data, but please be aware that no method of electronic storage is 100% secure. If you uninstall the app, this data may be removed, unless backed up by your device\'s operating system features.
We do not share your personal data with any third parties. Your data remains on your device and is not transmitted to us or any external servers.

Since your data is stored locally, you have full control over it. You can:
- Access and review your data within the app.
- Modify your profile information and measurements directly in the app.
- Delete your profile data by clearing app data through your device settings or uninstalling the application.

Our application is not intended for use by children under the age of 13 (or the relevant age in your jurisdiction). We do not knowingly collect personal information from children. If we become aware that a child has provided us with personal information, we will take steps to remove such information.

We may update our Privacy Policy from time to time. We will notify you of any changes by posting the new Privacy Policy within the app. You are advised to review this Privacy Policy periodically for any changes.
If you have any questions about this Privacy Policy, please contact us at [Your Support Email or Contact Method Here].

Take all measurements on the right side of the body.
Ensure the skin is dry and do not measure after exercise.
Pinch the skinfold firmly with your thumb and index finger. Place the caliper jaws perpendicular to the fold, 1 cm below your fingers.
Release the caliper trigger slowly and take the reading after 2 seconds.
Take at least two measurements at each site and average them if they differ by more than 1-2 mm.
1. Chest: A diagonal fold taken midway between the nipple and the anterior axillary line (front of the armpit).
2. Abdomen: A vertical fold taken 2 cm (about 1 inch) to the right of the navel.
3. Thigh: A vertical fold on the anterior midline of the thigh, midway between the hip and knee.
1. Triceps: A vertical fold on the posterior midline of the upper arm, halfway between the acromion (shoulder tip) and olecranon (elbow tip).
2. Suprailiac: A diagonal fold just above the iliac crest (hip bone) in line with the natural angle of the bone, taken at the anterior axillary line.
3. Thigh: A vertical fold on the anterior midline of the thigh, midway between the hip and knee.
3. Thigh: A vertical fold on the anterior midline of the thigh, midway between the hip and knee.
Chest: Diagonal fold, one-half the distance between the anterior axillary line and the nipple (men), or one-third of this distance (women).
Midaxillary: Vertical fold on the midaxillary line at the level of the xiphoid process (the bottom of the sternum).
Triceps: Vertical fold on the posterior midline of the upper arm, halfway between the acromion (shoulder tip) and the olecranon (elbow tip).
Subscapular: Diagonal fold (at a 45-degree angle) 1–2 cm below the inferior angle of the scapula (shoulder blade).
Abdomen: Vertical fold, 2 cm to the right side of the umbilicus (navel).
Suprailiac: Diagonal fold in line with the natural angle of the iliac crest taken in the anterior axillary line immediately superior to the iliac crest.
Thigh: Vertical fold on the anterior midline of the thigh, midway between the proximal border of the patella (upper knee) and the inguinal crease (hip).
